name: Red Panda
facts: Red pandas use their bushy tails as cozy blankets when they sleep!
They spend most of their lives up in trees and even sleep there.
Despite the name, they're actually more closely related to raccoons than giant pandas.

name: Axolotl
facts: Axolotls can regenerate their limbs, heart, and even parts of their brain!
They're permanent babies â€” they never fully metamorphose like other salamanders.
Wild axolotls are only found in one lake near Mexico City.

name: Quokka
facts: Quokkas are known as the happiest animals on Earth because they always look like they're smiling!
They live almost exclusively on Rottnest Island in Australia.
They can go months without drinking water by getting moisture from plants.

name: Fennec Fox
facts: Their enormous ears can be up to 6 inches long â€” half their body length!
Those big ears help them radiate body heat and stay cool in the Sahara Desert.
They're the smallest fox species in the world, weighing only 2-3 pounds.

name: Sea Otter
facts: Sea otters hold hands while sleeping so they don't drift apart!
They have the densest fur of any mammal â€” about 1 million hairs per square inch.
They use rocks as tools to crack open shellfish on their tummies.

name: Northern Pygmy Owl
facts: They're only about 6 inches tall â€” roughly the size of a soda can!
They have fake 'eye spots' on the back of their head to scare predators.
Despite their tiny size, they can hunt birds bigger than themselves.

name: Hedgehog
facts: A hedgehog has about 5,000 to 7,000 quills on its body!
When they encounter a new smell, they do something called 'self-anointing' â€” licking the object then spreading foamy saliva on their spines.
Baby hedgehogs are called hoglets!

name: Sugar Glider
facts: They can glide through the air up to 150 feet using a membrane between their legs!
Sugar gliders are marsupials, not rodents â€” they carry their babies in a pouch.
They got their name because they love sweet foods like nectar and fruit.

name: American Pika
facts: Pikas are tiny relatives of rabbits that live on mountain tops!
They make tiny haystacks of dried grass and flowers to survive winter.
Their adorable squeak can be heard echoing across rocky mountain slopes.

name: Dumbo Octopus
facts: They're named after Disney's Dumbo because of the ear-like fins on their head!
They live deeper than any other octopus â€” up to 13,000 feet below the surface.
Unlike most octopuses, they swallow their prey whole in one adorable gulp.

name: Slow Loris
facts: Slow lorises are one of the only venomous primates in the world!
They have an incredibly strong grip â€” they can hang from branches for hours.
Their huge, round eyes give them excellent night vision for nocturnal life.

name: Arctic Fox
facts: Arctic foxes change color with the seasons â€” white in winter, brown in summer!
They can survive temperatures as low as -58Â°F (-50Â°C).
Their fluffy tails are so thick they use them as face blankets in blizzards.

name: Pangolin
facts: Pangolins are the only mammals in the world completely covered in scales!
When scared, they roll into a perfect ball that even lions can't unroll.
A pangolin's tongue can be longer than its entire body.

name: Capybara
facts: Capybaras are the largest rodents on Earth, weighing up to 140 pounds!
They're incredibly social and will befriend literally any animal.
They can hold their breath underwater for up to five minutes.

name: Leaf Sheep Sea Slug
facts: They look like tiny cartoon sheep with leaf-like projections on their body!
They're one of the few animals that can photosynthesize â€” they eat algae and use the chloroplasts to make energy from sunlight.
They're only about 5mm long â€” smaller than a grain of rice!

name: Sand Cat
facts: Sand cats look like perpetual kittens â€” even adults have baby-like faces!
Their paws are covered in fur to protect them from hot desert sand.
They can survive without drinking water for weeks, getting moisture from prey.

name: Atlantic Puffin
facts: Puffins can carry 10+ fish in their beak at once, lined up perfectly!
Their colorful beaks actually fade to gray in winter and regrow their color in spring.
They flap their wings up to 400 times per minute to fly!

name: Chinchilla
facts: Chinchillas have the softest fur of any land animal â€” 20,000 hairs per square cm!
They take dust baths instead of water baths to keep their fur clean.
They can jump up to 6 feet in the air!

name: Seahorse
facts: Male seahorses are the ones who get pregnant and give birth!
They have no stomach â€” food passes through them so fast they must eat constantly.
Seahorse couples greet each other every morning with a special dance.

name: Wombat
facts: Wombats are the only animals in the world that poop cubes!
Their backward-facing pouch keeps dirt out while they dig burrows.
Their butt is made of mostly cartilage â€” they use it to block their burrow entrance!

name: Blue-Footed Booby
facts: Males show off their bright blue feet in a high-stepping dance to attract mates!
The bluer the feet, the healthier the bird â€” and the more attractive to partners.
They got the name 'booby' from the Spanish word 'bobo' meaning silly.

name: Otter Shrew
facts: Despite the name, they're not related to otters OR shrews!
They're one of Africa's most mysterious mammals â€” rarely seen in the wild.
They use their powerful flat tail to swim like a little torpedo.

name: Narwhal
facts: A narwhal's 'horn' is actually a giant tooth that can grow up to 10 feet long!
The tusk has millions of nerve endings â€” they can sense temperature and water pressure with it.
They're called the 'unicorns of the sea' and live in Arctic waters.

name: Meerkat
facts: Meerkats post sentinels that stand guard while the group forages!
They have a special call for different types of predators â€” essentially a language.
Baby meerkats are taught to eat scorpions by first being given ones with the stinger removed.

name: Koala
facts: Koalas sleep up to 22 hours a day because eucalyptus leaves give them so little energy!
Each koala has a unique nose print, just like human fingerprints.
Baby koalas are called joeys and are only the size of a jellybean when born.

name: Mantis Shrimp
facts: They can see 16 types of color receptors â€” humans only have 3!
Their punch accelerates faster than a bullet and can break aquarium glass.
Despite their power, they're absolutely gorgeous â€” often rainbow-colored.

name: Clouded Leopard
facts: They can hang upside down from branches using just their hind feet!
Their canine teeth are the longest relative to body size of any wild cat.
They're one of the best climbers in the cat family â€” they can climb down trees headfirst.

name: Bee Hummingbird
facts: They're the smallest bird in the world â€” only 2 inches long and lighter than a penny!
Their heart beats up to 1,260 times per minute.
They can fly backwards, sideways, and even upside down.

name: Emperor Tamarin
facts: They're named for their magnificent mustache that resembles Emperor Wilhelm II!
The whole family group helps raise the babies â€” dads do most of the carrying.
They weigh less than a pound but have enormous personality.

name: Moon Jellyfish
facts: Moon jellyfish have no brain, no heart, and no blood â€” yet they've survived for 500 million years!
They're about 95% water.
They glow with a beautiful blue bioluminescence under UV light.

name: Pygmy Marmoset
facts: They're the smallest monkeys in the world â€” small enough to fit in your palm!
They can rotate their heads 180 degrees, almost like an owl.
They communicate with ultrasonic calls that humans can't even hear.

name: Snow Leopard
facts: Snow leopards can't roar â€” they make a purring sound instead!
Their tails are almost as long as their body and they wrap them around their face to stay warm.
They can leap up to 50 feet in a single bound.

name: Clownfish
facts: Clownfish are immune to the stings of their host anemone thanks to a special mucus!
All clownfish are born male â€” the dominant one becomes female.
They do a little wiggling dance to keep their anemone clean and healthy.

name: Red-Eyed Tree Frog
facts: Their bright red eyes are a defense mechanism called 'startle coloration' â€” they flash them to scare predators!
They can change their skin color slightly depending on their mood.
Their tadpoles can hatch early if they sense a predator shaking their egg leaf.

name: Platypus
facts: The platypus is one of only five species of mammals that lay eggs!
Males have venomous spurs on their hind legs.
They detect prey underwater by sensing the electric fields generated by muscle contractions.

name: Manatee
facts: Manatees are also called 'sea cows' and they're gentle vegetarians!
They replace their teeth continuously throughout their lives â€” like a conveyor belt.
Early sailors mistook them for mermaids!

name: Kakapo
facts: The kakapo is the world's only flightless parrot â€” and the heaviest one too!
There are fewer than 250 left, and every single one has a name.
They smell like honey and flowers, which unfortunately makes them easy for predators to find.

name: Flying Squirrel
facts: They don't actually fly â€” they glide using a furry membrane called a patagium!
Japanese dwarf flying squirrels are considered one of the cutest animals on Earth.
They can glide distances of up to 300 feet between trees.

name: Blobfish
facts: In their natural deep-sea habitat, they actually look like normal fish â€” the 'blobby' look only happens at the surface!
They live at depths where the pressure is 120 times greater than at the surface.
They don't have muscles â€” they just float above the ocean floor waiting for food to drift by.

name: Alpaca
facts: Alpacas hum to communicate â€” each hum means something different!
They have incredibly soft fleece that comes in 22 natural colors.
When annoyed, they spit â€” but they usually only spit at other alpacas, not humans.

name: Leafy Seadragon
facts: Their leaf-like appendages are purely for camouflage â€” they don't use them to swim!
They're the marine emblem of the state of South Australia.
Like seahorses, the males carry and protect the eggs.

name: Aye-Aye
facts: They have a super-long, skinny middle finger they use to tap on trees and fish out grubs!
They're the world's largest nocturnal primate.
In Madagascar folklore, they're considered omens â€” making them one of the most misunderstood animals.

name: Peacock Spider
facts: Males do an elaborate dance with their colorful belly flaps raised to impress females!
They're only about 5mm long â€” smaller than a pencil eraser.
If the female isn't impressed by his dance, she might eat him!

name: Numbat
facts: Numbats eat up to 20,000 termites a day using their long, sticky tongue!
They're one of the few marsupials active during the daytime.
They have beautiful orange-brown fur with white stripes â€” nature's racing stripes!

name: Golden Poison Frog
facts: One golden poison frog has enough toxin to kill 10 grown adults!
Despite being deadly, they're actually amazing parents who carry their tadpoles on their back.
Their bright golden color is nature's way of saying 'don't touch me!'

name: Okapi
facts: Okapis look like a zebra-giraffe mashup, but they're actually the giraffe's only living relative!
Their tongues are so long (14-18 inches) they can lick their own ears.
They weren't known to western science until 1901 â€” one of the last large mammals discovered.

name: Harp Seal Pup
facts: Harp seal pups are born with fluffy white fur that's so iconic it became a symbol of conservation!
They can swim and dive within just a few weeks of being born.
Their white coat helps them blend into the Arctic ice to hide from predators.

name: Kiwi Bird
facts: Kiwis are the only birds with nostrils at the tip of their beak!
They have whiskers like a cat that help them navigate at night.
Their eggs are huge â€” up to 20% of the mother's body weight!

name: Fossa
facts: The fossa is Madagascar's top predator â€” it looks like a cat but is related to the mongoose!
They're one of the few predators agile enough to hunt lemurs through the trees.
Their tail is as long as their body, giving them incredible balance.

name: Tarsier
facts: Each of their eyeballs is as big as their entire brain!
They can rotate their heads nearly 180 degrees like an owl.
They're the only fully carnivorous primates â€” they eat insects, lizards, and even birds.

name: Red Fox
facts: Red foxes can hear a mouse squeak from 100 feet away!
They use the Earth's magnetic field to pounce on prey hidden under snow.
A fox's tail, called a 'brush,' helps them balance and stay warm in winter.

name: Mandrill
facts: Mandrills have the most colorful faces of any mammal â€” bright blue and red!
The brighter a male's face colors, the higher his rank in the group.
They're the largest species of monkey in the world.

name: Harpy Eagle
facts: Their talons are as long as a grizzly bear's claws â€” up to 5 inches!
They can snatch monkeys and sloths right out of the treetops.
Despite their power, they build cozy nests that they reuse for years.

name: Glass Frog
facts: Their belly skin is completely transparent â€” you can see their heart beating!
Glass frog dads guard their eggs for weeks, keeping them moist and safe.
When sleeping on green leaves, their transparent skin acts as perfect camouflage.

name: Emperor Penguin
facts: Emperor penguin dads balance their egg on their feet for 2 months in Antarctic winter!
They can dive deeper than any other bird â€” over 1,800 feet.
They huddle together for warmth, taking turns being in the cozy center.

name: Star-Nosed Mole
facts: Their star-shaped nose has 22 tentacles that can detect food in under a quarter of a second!
They're the fastest-eating mammal â€” they can identify and eat food in 120 milliseconds.
They can even smell underwater by blowing bubbles and re-inhaling them.

name: Flamingo
facts: Flamingos are born white â€” they turn pink from eating shrimp and algae!
They can only eat with their heads upside down.
A group of flamingos is called a 'flamboyance.'

name: Panther Chameleon
facts: Their eyes can move independently â€” looking in two different directions at once!
They change color not for camouflage but to communicate mood and temperature.
Their tongue can shoot out faster than a fighter jet takes off.

name: Ring-Tailed Lemur
facts: They have 'stink fights' where males waft scent from their wrists at each other!
Ring-tailed lemurs spend more time on the ground than any other lemur species.
They love sunbathing and will sit with arms outstretched in a yoga-like pose.

name: Thorny Devil
facts: They can drink water through their skin â€” channels between their scales collect dew and rain!
They have a fake 'head' on the back of their neck to confuse predators.
Despite looking fearsome, they're harmless and only eat ants.

name: Red-Crowned Crane
facts: Their elaborate mating dance involves leaping, wing-flapping, and bowing!
In Japan, they're symbols of luck, longevity, and fidelity.
They mate for life and pairs perform duets together, singing in perfect unison.

name: Blue Dragon Sea Slug
facts: They float upside down on the ocean surface, using surface tension to stay afloat!
They eat venomous Portuguese man-of-wars and store the stinging cells for self-defense.
Despite being only about an inch long, they're considered one of the most beautiful sea creatures.

name: Wolverine
facts: Wolverines can take down prey 5 times their size, including caribou!
They have incredibly powerful jaws that can bite through frozen meat and bone.
Despite their fierce reputation, they're actually part of the weasel family.

name: Cassowary
facts: Cassowaries have a large bony helmet called a casque on top of their head!
They're considered the most dangerous bird in the world due to their powerful kick.
They play a vital role in rainforest ecology by spreading seeds of over 200 plant species.

name: Margay
facts: Margays can rotate their ankles 180 degrees, letting them climb down trees headfirst!
They're one of only two cat species that can hang from branches by their hind feet.
They mimic the calls of baby monkeys to lure adult monkeys closer.

name: Blue Ringed Octopus
facts: Despite being the size of a golf ball, they carry enough venom to kill 26 adults!
Their bright blue rings flash as a warning when they feel threatened.
They're actually quite shy and will only bite as an absolute last resort.

name: Pygmy Hippopotamus
facts: Pygmy hippos are only about 1/10 the size of regular hippos â€” about as big as a large pig!
They secrete a pink, oily fluid that acts as natural sunscreen and moisturizer.
Unlike regular hippos, they prefer to be alone and spend most time in forests, not water.

name: Binturong
facts: Binturongs smell exactly like buttered popcorn â€” it's from a chemical in their scent glands!
They're also called 'bearcats' even though they're related to neither bears nor cats.
Their prehensile tail works like a fifth limb for gripping branches.

name: Proboscis Monkey
facts: Males have enormous droopy noses that amplify their calls through the forest!
The bigger the nose, the more attractive the male is to females.
They're excellent swimmers and can even swim underwater for up to 20 meters.

name: Snowy Owl
facts: Snowy owls are one of the few owls that hunt during the day!
Males get whiter as they age â€” the oldest males are almost pure white.
They can eat up to 1,600 lemmings per year â€” that's 3 to 5 per day.

name: Giant Panda
facts: Pandas spend up to 14 hours a day eating â€” they need about 28 pounds of bamboo daily!
Newborn pandas are tiny â€” about the size of a stick of butter.
They have a special 'pseudo thumb' (an extended wrist bone) that helps them grip bamboo.

name: Three-Toed Sloth
facts: Sloths are so slow that algae grows on their fur, giving them a green tint!
They can hold their breath for up to 40 minutes â€” longer than dolphins.
They only come down from trees about once a week to go to the bathroom.

name: Secretary Bird
facts: Secretary birds stomp on snakes with a force five times their own body weight!
They got their name from the quill-like feathers that look like a secretary's pens tucked behind their ear.
They can walk up to 20 miles a day hunting across the African savanna.

name: Porcupine
facts: A porcupine has about 30,000 quills that can detach and stick into predators!
Their quills have antibiotic properties that help prevent infection if they accidentally poke themselves.
Baby porcupines are born with soft quills that harden within a few days.

name: Serval
facts: Servals have the longest legs relative to body size of any cat!
They catch their prey with a spectacular pouncing leap up to 10 feet in the air.
Their enormous ears can rotate independently to pinpoint sounds with incredible accuracy.

name: Vampire Squid
facts: Despite their spooky name, they don't suck blood â€” they eat 'marine snow' (falling particles)!
They can turn themselves inside out to defend against predators.
Their eyes are the largest in proportion to body size of any animal.

name: Shoebill Stork
facts: Their massive shoe-shaped bill can be up to 9 inches long and 4 inches wide!
They can stand motionless for hours waiting to ambush fish â€” like living statues.
When they spot prey, they lunge with their entire body in a move called 'collapsing.'

name: Gerenuk
facts: Gerenuks stand on their hind legs to reach leaves that other antelope can't!
They never need to drink water â€” they get all their moisture from plants.
Their name means 'giraffe-necked' in Somali.

name: Cuttlefish
facts: Cuttlefish can change color, pattern, AND texture in milliseconds!
They have three hearts and green-blue blood.
Males sometimes disguise themselves as females to sneak past rivals and mate.

name: Resplendent Quetzal
facts: Males grow spectacular tail feathers up to 3 feet long during mating season!
The Aztecs and Maya considered them sacred â€” their feathers were worth more than gold.
They can't survive in captivity, which is why they're symbols of freedom in Guatemala.

name: Aardvark
facts: Aardvark means 'earth pig' in Afrikaans, but they're not related to pigs at all!
They can eat up to 50,000 ants and termites in a single night.
Their thick skin protects them from insect bites while they raid ant colonies.

name: Iberian Lynx
facts: They were once the most endangered cat in the world with fewer than 100 left!
Conservation efforts brought them back from the brink â€” there are now over 1,000.
Their distinctive beard and ear tufts make them one of the most striking wild cats.

name: Painted Turtle
facts: They can survive being frozen solid in winter and thaw out in spring!
Their colorful red and yellow markings earned them the name 'painted.'
They bask in the sun to regulate their body temperature and can stack on top of each other.

name: Saiga Antelope
facts: Their bizarre bulbous nose filters dust in summer and warms frigid air in winter!
They've roamed the Earth since the Ice Age alongside woolly mammoths.
Females give birth to twins and the calves can run within just a few hours.

name: Jerboa
facts: Jerboas can jump up to 10 feet in a single bound â€” that's over 10 times their body length!
Their kangaroo-like hind legs make them one of the bounciest rodents.
They're nocturnal desert dwellers and never need to drink water.

name: Osprey
facts: Ospreys are the only raptors whose outer toe is reversible, letting them grip slippery fish with two toes in front and two behind!
They dive feet-first into water at high speed to catch fish.
They build enormous nests that they return to year after year, sometimes for decades.

name: Malayan Tapir
facts: Their distinctive black and white pattern actually works as camouflage in moonlit forests!
They use their flexible snout like a mini elephant trunk to grab leaves.
Baby tapirs look completely different from adults â€” they have spots and stripes like watermelons.

name: Bush Baby
facts: Bush babies can jump up to 8 feet straight up â€” like a tiny furry rocket!
Their huge eyes give them incredible night vision in the dark forests.
They got their name because their cries sound eerily like a human baby.

name: Gharial
facts: Their long, thin snout is perfectly designed for catching fish â€” like living fishing poles!
Males have a bulbous growth on their nose called a 'ghara' that amplifies their calls.
They're one of the most critically endangered crocodilians with fewer than 650 adults left.

name: Dik-Dik
facts: Dik-diks are named after the alarm calls the females make â€” 'dik-dik, dik-dik!'
They're one of the smallest antelopes, standing only 12-16 inches tall.
They mate for life and are always found in devoted pairs.

name: Coconut Crab
facts: They're the largest land-living arthropod, with a leg span up to 3 feet!
Their claws are strong enough to crack open coconuts â€” hence the name.
They have an incredible sense of smell and can detect food from miles away.

name: Superb Lyrebird
facts: Lyrebirds are the world's best mimics â€” they can copy chainsaws, car alarms, and camera shutters!
Males create elaborate stages by clearing forest floor patches for their dance performances.
Their tail feathers take 7 years to fully develop and look like a lyre instrument.

name: Sun Bear
facts: Sun bears are the smallest bears in the world, about the size of a large dog!
Each sun bear has a unique chest patch â€” like a fingerprint.
Their incredibly long tongues (up to 10 inches) help them slurp honey from beehives.

name: Mata Mata Turtle
facts: They look like a pile of dead leaves and bark â€” the ultimate underwater disguise!
They catch prey by opening their huge mouth so fast it creates a vacuum that sucks fish in.
They don't chase food at all â€” they wait perfectly still until prey wanders too close.

name: Hoatzin
facts: Hoatzin chicks have claws on their wings that let them climb trees like little dinosaurs!
They're also called 'stinkbirds' because they digest food like cows and smell terrible.
They're the only birds known to ruminate, fermenting leaves in their crop.

name: Mouse Deer
facts: Mouse deer are the world's smallest hoofed animals â€” some weigh less than 2 pounds!
They're not actually mice or deer â€” they belong to their own unique family.
Males have tiny fangs instead of antlers that they use in territorial disputes.

name: Bird of Paradise
facts: Males perform the most elaborate dances in the animal kingdom to impress females!
Some species have feathers so dark they absorb 99.95% of light â€” the blackest black in nature.
There are over 40 species and each has its own unique dance routine.

name: Red Squirrel
facts: Red squirrels can find buried nuts under a foot of snow using their incredible sense of smell!
They can fall from 30 feet without getting hurt, using their tail as a parachute.
Each red squirrel buries thousands of nuts and can remember most hiding spots.

name: Kit Fox
facts: Kit foxes are the smallest fox species in North America, weighing just 3-6 pounds!
Their enormous ears help them hear prey underground and cool off in desert heat.
They can survive without drinking water, getting all moisture from their food.

name: Japanese Macaque
facts: Japanese macaques love soaking in hot springs during winter â€” just like tiny spa lovers!
They make snowballs just for fun, making them one of the few animals that play with objects.
They're also called 'snow monkeys' and are the most northern-living non-human primates.

name: Holland Lop Rabbit
facts: Rabbits 'binky' when happy â€” they jump in the air and twist their body with joy!
Their floppy ears can be up to 10 inches long and hang below their jaw.
They purr by softly grinding their teeth when content, just like cats.

name: Pomeranian
facts: Pomeranians descended from large sled dogs â€” they used to be much bigger!
Queen Victoria had a tiny Pomeranian that made the breed popular as small companions.
Despite their tiny size, they think they're big dogs and will bravely confront much larger animals.

name: Dwarf Hamster
facts: Roborovski dwarf hamsters are the smallest hamster species, fitting easily in the palm of your hand!
They can run up to 6 miles a night on their exercise wheels.
Their cheek pouches can stretch to triple the size of their head to store food.

name: Persian Cat
facts: Persian cats have been adored for over 4,000 years â€” they're one of the oldest cat breeds!
Their luxurious fur can grow up to 8 inches long.
They're known as 'furniture with fur' because they love lounging around all day.

name: Ferret
facts: Ferrets do a 'war dance' when they're excited â€” hopping sideways and bumping into things!
They sleep up to 18 hours a day but are incredibly energetic when awake.
A group of ferrets is called a 'business.'

name: Golden Retriever
facts: Golden retrievers have such gentle mouths they can carry an egg without breaking it!
They're one of the most popular therapy and service dog breeds in the world.
Their love of water is legendary â€” they were originally bred to retrieve waterfowl.

name: River Otter
facts: River otters slide on their bellies down muddy and snowy slopes just for fun!
They can close their ears and nostrils underwater to swim and dive.
Otter families play together constantly â€” wrestling, chasing, and sliding.

name: Asian Elephant
facts: Baby elephants suck their trunks for comfort, just like human babies suck their thumbs!
Asian elephants are incredibly intelligent and can recognize themselves in mirrors.
They mourn their dead and have been seen gently touching the bones of deceased family members.

name: Munchkin Cat
facts: Munchkin cats have short legs but can run just as fast as regular cats!
They love to sit up on their hind legs like little meerkats.
They're sometimes called the 'corgis of the cat world' because of their short legs.

name: Corgi
facts: Corgis were originally bred to herd cattle by nipping at their heels!
According to Welsh legend, fairies used to ride them like horses.
Their name means 'dwarf dog' in Welsh.

name: Shiba Inu
facts: Shiba Inus do the 'Shiba scream' â€” a unique, loud yell when they're excited or upset!
They're one of the oldest and smallest native Japanese dog breeds.
They're famously clean dogs that groom themselves like cats.

name: Scottish Fold Cat
facts: Their folded ears give them an owl-like appearance that makes them irresistibly cute!
All Scottish Folds descend from a single barn cat named Susie found in Scotland in 1961.
They're known for sitting in the 'Buddha position' with their legs stretched out.

name: Red Ruffed Lemur
facts: Red ruffed lemurs are one of the largest pollinators in the world â€” they pollinate trees with their snouts!
They build nests high in the trees for their babies, which is unusual for primates.
They can hang upside down by their feet to reach fruit on thin branches.

name: Little Blue Penguin
facts: Little blue penguins are the smallest penguin species, standing only about 13 inches tall!
They come ashore at dusk in an adorable parade called the 'penguin parade.'
Unlike most penguins, their feathers are blue instead of black.

name: Red Panda Cub
facts: Red panda cubs are born with their eyes and ears sealed shut and don't open them for weeks!
They stay with their mother for about a year before venturing out on their own.
Baby red pandas are so small at birth they fit in the palm of your hand.

name: Pygmy Goat
facts: Pygmy goats are incredibly playful and love to jump on everything they can find!
They're social animals that can become depressed without companions.
Despite their tiny size, they were originally bred for milk production in Africa.

name: Harbor Seal
facts: Harbor seal pups can swim within minutes of being born!
They can sleep underwater, surfacing automatically to breathe every 30 minutes.
Each harbor seal has a unique pattern of spots, like a fingerprint.

name: Arctic Hare
facts: Arctic hares can run up to 40 mph â€” one of the fastest animals in the Arctic!
They huddle together in groups of up to 100 to keep warm in blizzards.
Their thick white fur turns blue-gray in summer for camouflage.

name: Clouded Leopard Cub
facts: Clouded leopard cubs are born with solid dark spots that develop into their cloudy pattern!
They start climbing trees at just 6 weeks old â€” earlier than most wild cats.
Cubs are incredibly playful and practice their climbing by hanging upside down from branches.

name: Pygmy Slow Loris
facts: Pygmy slow lorises are one of only a handful of venomous mammals!
They raise their arms above their head in a cute pose when threatened â€” accessing toxin glands near their elbows.
They mark their territory by washing their hands in their own urine.

name: Pallas's Cat
facts: Pallas's cats are famous for their hilariously grumpy expressions!
They have the longest and densest fur of any cat species to survive harsh winters.
Their round pupils (unlike other small cats' slits) give them an almost human-like stare.

name: Quoll
facts: Quolls are adorable spotted marsupials that are surprisingly fierce predators!
They're sometimes called 'native cats' but they're not related to cats at all.
Baby quolls ride on their mother's back once they outgrow the pouch.

name: Coatimundi
facts: Coatis hold their long, ringed tails straight up while walking â€” like little antenna flags!
They can rotate their ankles 180 degrees to climb down trees headfirst.
They have an incredibly flexible snout that they use like a finger to search for food.

name: Fawn (Baby Deer)
facts: Fawns are born nearly scentless to protect them from predators!
Their white spots mimic dappled sunlight on the forest floor for camouflage.
A newborn fawn can stand and walk within 20 minutes of being born.

name: Raccoon
facts: Raccoons have incredibly sensitive hands with 4 times more touch receptors than most mammals!
They wash their food before eating â€” their name literally means 'one who washes' in Powhatan.
They can remember solutions to tasks for up to 3 years.

name: Bush Dog
facts: Bush dogs are tiny, stubby-legged wild dogs that look like bear-dog hybrids!
They have webbed feet that make them excellent swimmers.
They hunt in packs and can take down prey much larger than themselves.

name: Stoat
facts: Stoats turn completely white in winter and are called 'ermine' â€” their fur was worn by royalty!
Despite being tiny, they can take down rabbits 10 times their size.
They do a hypnotic 'war dance' that mesmerizes prey into freezing.

name: Baby Hippopotamus
facts: Baby hippos are born underwater and must swim to the surface for their first breath!
They nurse underwater by folding their ears and closing their nostrils.
Newborn hippos weigh about 100 pounds but are considered tiny for their species.

name: Sea Bunny
facts: Sea bunnies are actually sea slugs with fuzzy-looking sensory organs that look like bunny ears!
They're only about 1 inch long and live in the waters around Japan.
Their fluffy appearance is caused by tiny rod-like structures called caryophyllidia.

name: Tanuki (Raccoon Dog)
facts: Tanuki are not raccoons â€” they're actually the only canid that hibernates!
In Japanese folklore, they're mischievous shapeshifters with magical powers.
They're one of the oldest canid species, virtually unchanged for millions of years.

name: Philippine Eagle-Owl
facts: Philippine eagle-owls are one of the largest owls in the Philippines, with striking orange eyes!
They're incredibly elusive and rarely seen, making them a prized sighting for birdwatchers.
They mate for life and both parents share duties caring for their single chick.

name: Baby Giraffe
facts: Baby giraffes drop 6 feet to the ground when born â€” and stand up within 30 minutes!
Each giraffe's spot pattern is unique, like human fingerprints.
Baby giraffes can run with their mothers within 10 hours of being born.

name: Red-Eyed Crocodile Skink
facts: They look like tiny dragons with spiky armor and bright orange rings around their eyes!
When scared, they freeze and play dead rather than running away.
They're one of the few skink species that vocalize â€” they squeak when startled.

name: Baby Orangutan
facts: Baby orangutans cling to their mothers for the first 2 years of life and nurse until age 6!
They're incredibly intelligent and can learn to use tools by watching their mothers.
Orangutan means 'person of the forest' in Malay.

name: Patagonian Mara
facts: Patagonian maras look like a cross between a rabbit, deer, and dog!
They mate for life â€” the male follows his partner everywhere, even to the bathroom.
They can leap up to 6 feet in the air and run at speeds up to 28 mph.

name: Pine Marten
facts: Pine martens are so agile they can catch squirrels in the treetops!
They have a cream-yellow bib on their chest that's unique to each individual.
They help control grey squirrel populations, which helps native red squirrels recover.

name: Baby Pangolin
facts: Baby pangolins ride on their mother's tail like a tiny armored backpack!
Their scales are soft at birth and harden within a few days.
They curl up with their mother in a protective ball when they sense danger.

name: Ocelot
facts: Ocelots have the most beautiful rosette-patterned fur of any small wild cat!
They're excellent swimmers and don't avoid water like most cats.
Salvador DalÃ­ had a pet ocelot named Babou that he took everywhere, even on ocean liners.
